Issues.Title: [dnceng-bot] Branch `winforms/release/9.0` can't be merged to Azdo internal branch
Issues.Body:
Branch [release/9.0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/commits/release/9.0/) in `dotnet/winforms` repo can't be mirrored from GitHub to Azure [internal/release/9.0](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-winforms?version=GBinternal%2Frelease%2F9.0&_a=history) via internal merge. 

There are conflicting commits in the target branch.
The branch is configured to be mirrored via automated merge. 
The situation is rare but normal. The target branch is expected to receive manual commits in the Azure DevOps clone, which could cause conflict.

Conflicts need to be **resolved to unblock the code flow**.

- you can resolve the issue by resolving the conflict in the **target branch only**. 
    - Please make sure that the changes sensitive from security perspective are not published ahead of time to GitHub!
- reverting the extra commits in the Azdo target branch.
- checking the logs of the mirroring process in the [mirroring pipeline](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_build?definitionId=1387).
- you can disable the mirroring of the branch in the [configuration file](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-mirroring?path=/dnceng-subscriptions.jsonc).
- you can ask @dotnet/dnceng for help or read the [documentation](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-mirroring?path=/README.md).

Please close this issue once the conflict is resolved.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[dnceng-bot] Branch `winforms/release/9.0` can't be merged to Azdo internal branch" (#13817)

Issues.Title: Add judgement "IsHandleCreated" in OwnerDraw
Issues.Body: Fixes #13823 ## Root Cause The `OwnerDraw` property of the Button control incorrectly returns `false` when `BackgroundImage` is set during early initialization. This is due to the `OwnerDraw` logic checking `BackgroundImage == null` before the control's handle is created, which causes a premature fallback to the system renderer. As a result, even though `BackgroundImage` is later assigned, it is ignored during rendering in `FlatStyle.Standard` mode. ## Proposed changes - Add judgement `IsHandleCreated` in property `OwnerDraw` of the Button.cs ## Customer Impact - The BackgroundImage of Button can be displayed when the FlatStyle is Standard in DrakMode ## Regression? - Yes ## Risk - Minimal ## Screenshots ### Before The BackgroundImage of Button is not displayed when the FlatStyle is Standard in DrakMode ### After The BackgroundImage of Button displayed when the FlatStyle is Standard in DrakMode ## Test methodology - Manually ## Test environment(s) - .net 10.0.0-rc.1.25418.105 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13824)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Add judgement "IsHandleCreated" in OwnerDraw" (#13824)

Issues.Title: Dark Mode: The BackgroundImage of Button is not displayed when the FlatStyle is Standard in DrakMode
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET SDK 10.0.100.rc.2.25419.103 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? No ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? The issue also can reproduce on .NET SDK 10.0 Prevview7. there has the known issue https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/13720 to track. after the fix of PR https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13809, the issue has been fixed when the FlatStyle is Flat/Popup, but still reproduce when the FaltStyle is Standard ### Issue description The BackgroundImage of Button is not displayed when the FlatStyle is Standard in DrakMode **.NET 10.0 rc.2 & rc.1 results:** **.NET 10.0 preview7 results:** **.NET 9.0 results:** ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create a winforms app, a form and a button with a background image. 2. Run the project in DarkMode 3. Observe results
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dark Mode: The BackgroundImage of Button is not displayed when the FlatStyle is Standard in DrakMode" (#13823)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "[release/10.0] Source code updates from dotnet/dotnet" (#13815)

Issues.Title: Remove experimental state for DarkMode
Issues.Body:
## Removing Experimental Status for Dark Mode
We are preparing to remove the experimental flag from Dark Mode in WinForms.

A broad range of customers with diverse applications have tested Dark Mode, helping us reach the quality bar we aimed for and strengthening our confidence in removing its experimental status.

### Important Considerations

WinForms is built as a managed wrapper around native Win32 controls. This architecture introduces inherent limitations in how theming and rendering behave, especially in Dark Mode. While Windows continues to evolve its support for theming, some constraints remain:

- **Rendering Limitations:** Certain controls may not render perfectly in Dark Mode due to the underlying Win32 behavior. These imperfections are expected and will not be treated as bugs.
- **Security and Compatibility First:** We prioritize security and backward compatibility over perfect visual fidelity. Changes that risk breaking classic rendering or introduce regressions will be avoided.
- **Ongoing Improvements:** As Windows improves Win32 theming, WinForms will adapt accordingly. You can expect Dark Mode rendering to improve over time, but not all issues will be resolved immediately.
- **Contrast and A11Y Edge Cases:** Some edge cases may result in suboptimal contrast or fail to meet certain, specific A11Y guidelines. While dark mode for many users addresses one major A11Y concern (general bright screens with too much strain to the eyes): If your application requires strict contrast compliance, we recommend using either Classic (light) mode or High Contrast mode.

## Summary

Dark Mode in WinForms is stable and ready for broader use, but it is not perfect or does not apply to every control area. We ask developers to understand the trade-offs involved and to plan accordingly. 

This issue tracks the PR that will remove the experimental flag and formalize Dark Mode as a supported feature.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remove experimental state for DarkMode" (#13805)

Issues.Title: Remove Experimental attribute for dark mode
Issues.Body:
Fixes #13805 

* Removes the ExperimentalAttribute for all Dark Mode (SetColorMode) related APIs.
* Updates the docs for `Application.SetColorMode` to reflect latest developments.
* Removes #Pragma 5001

Issues.Title: Dark Mode: The ForeColor & BackColor properties are not working for the controls
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET SDK 10.0.100-rc.1.25414.103 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? No ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? Yes, The issue reproduce on .NET SDK 10.0.100-preview.6.25358.103 build, not reproduce on .NET SDK 10.0.100-preview.5.25277.114 ### Issue description The ForeColor & BackColor properties are not working for the controls: **The ForeColor is not working for Button control The BackColor is not working for Button, TextBox, DomainUpDown, NumericUpDown, RichTextBox, MaskedTextBox contorls** **.NET SDK 10.0.100-preview.6.25358.103** **.NET SDK 10.0.100-preview.5.25277.114** ### Steps to reproduce 1. Open the attached application [ReproApplication.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21783026/ReproApplication.zip) 2. Build & run the project 3. Observe the results
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dark Mode: The ForeColor & BackColor properties are not working for the controls" (#13813)

Issues.Title: Remove 5002 Experimental state for UI Async area
Issues.Body:
This PR removes the experimental status of the UI Async APIs:

* `Form.ShowAsync`
* `Form.ShowDialogAsync`
* `TaskDialog.ShowDialogAsync`

It also amends the docs with additional information about best practices for using ShowAsync in MultiForm / ToolWindow-async scenarios.

 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13811)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove 5002 Experimental state for UI Async area" (#13811)

Issues.Title: Improve Form.ShowAsync and Form.ShowDialogAsync
Issues.Body:
* Added unit tests for `ShowAsync`
* Improved `ShowAsync` and `ShowDialogAsync` by associating the Form via `WeakReference` with the returned Task's `AsyncState`, so that it's easy to retrieve the Form from a returned Task in `Task.WhenAny` scenarios.
* Added unit test for that particular scenario.

 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13808)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Improve Form.ShowAsync and Form.ShowDialogAsync" (#13808)

Issues.Title: Designer doesn't show CommandParameter property in PropertyGrid and doesn't serialize its value, even if they are of type string.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 7 - .NET 10

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Was introduced in .NET 7 - doesn't apply.

### Issue description

You cannot find the `CommandParameter` property of a respective control which provides it in the property browser at Design time. The `CommandParameter` can only be _bound_ to a data source's property.

### Steps to reproduce

* Place a Button on a .NET 7+ WinForms App on the Form.
* Try to find the `CommandParameter` property in the PropertyGrid.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Designer doesn't show CommandParameter property in PropertyGrid and doesn't serialize its value, even if they are of type string." (#13801)

Issues.Title: CommandParameter property: Provide designer support and control CodeDOM serialization
Issues.Body:
Fixes #13801.

Affected Controls are

- `ButtonBase`
- `ToolStripItem`

Fixes:
- `CommandParameter` is now shown in the property browser, and string values can be directly entered.
- If `CommandParameter` is effectively of type `string`, the values are getting CodeDOM-serialized and -deseriaslized.

 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13802)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "CommandParameter property: Provide designer support and control CodeDOM serialization" (#13802)

Issues.Title: Draw background image for button in dark mode
Issues.Body: Fixes #13720 ## Proposed changes - Add `DrawBackgroundImage` in the method `PaintImage` of the `ButtonBaseAdapter.cs` ## Customer Impact - Button background image can be displayed in Winform dark mode ## Regression? - Yes ## Risk - Minimal ## Screenshots ### Before The button background images are no longer displayed in dark mode. ### After The button background images can be displayed in dark mode ## Test methodology - Manually ## Test environment(s) - .net 10.0.0-rc.1.25413.101 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13809)

Issues.Title: Default value for "ToolTip.AutoPopDelay" causes infinite tooltip (on Win 11 24H2 only?)
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

The sample targets .NET Framework 4.8. NET6 and .NET8 - the problem happens for all of them. Same for .NET 9.


### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

The default value for "ToolTip.AutoPopDelay" causes an infinite tooltip that never goes away (tested on two systems). 
If I change it to 4999 or 5001, it works as expected and the tooltip is hidden after the delay.

The [doc](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.tooltip.autopopdelay?view=windowsdesktop-8.0) does not say anything about this. But it also says "The maximum time you can delay a popup is 5000 milliseconds", which is probably also wrong, as the value 10000 works as expected.


Maybe related to the OS version (Win 11 24H2, verified on two machines)? I tested the .NET 4.8 version of my sample also with Windows Server 2019, and here the tooltip is closed after 5 seconds.

### Steps to reproduce

See attached sample: [ToolTipTest.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21742135/ToolTipTest.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Default value for "ToolTip.AutoPopDelay" causes infinite tooltip (on Win 11 24H2 only?)" (#13800)

Issues.Title: ToolStripButton does not visually distinguish between Checked and Indeterminate states
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET 10.0 SDK build: 10.0.100-rc.1.25412.107 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? No ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? No ### Issue description `ToolStripButton` supports three check states: `Unchecked`, `Checked`, and `Indeterminate`. However, the visual appearance of the `Checked `and `Indeterminate `states is nearly identical in most themes and renderers, including `ToolStripSystemRenderer` and `ToolStripProfessionalRenderer`. This makes it difficult or impossible for users to distinguish the two states by looking at the UI. Classic mode: Dark mode: ### Steps to reproduce 1. Add a ToolStripButton to a ToolStrip 2. Set CheckOnClick = true and CheckState = Indeterminate 3. Toggle between Checked and Indeterminate states in runtime 4. Observe the UI no meaningful visual difference between the two states
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ToolStripButton does not visually distinguish between Checked and Indeterminate states" (#13804)

Issues.Title: Survey - 2025 Repo Survey
Issues.Body:
Hi all,

Over the last few years we've been doing annual surveys to see how well we're doing engaging with the community. This year I'm quite a bit behind schedule, but here is the survey [link](https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/TZHNJ2W). If you would be so kind as to take a few minutes to fill this out we would greatly appreciate your feedback!

~Merrie and the whole WinForms team
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Survey - 2025 Repo Survey" (#13806)
